Message



Before you print: all messages must be approved by your Communication Council representative prior to printing and/or distribution.


Consider the following when preparing your piece:


What is the purpose for the piece?

Remember not everyone is familiar with what you do. Just giving them the name of a program or event may not be enough. A brief description is often helpful.


Required details

Include important details like date, time, location, cost, contact info, links to info on the Web, etc.


The broader university mission

When possible, find ways to relate your message to the mission of the university. This helps your audience better understand the university and further clarifies the purpose of your communication.


Writing resources

We recommend using these resources to maintain consistency in editorial and publication writing campus-wide:

  • LDS Terminology Guide (supersedes the University Terminology Guide, Chicago, and Merriam-Webster)
  • University Terminology Guide (supersedes Chicago and Merriam-Webster)
  • Chicago Manual of Style, 15th edition
  • Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary, 11th edition

Creative latitude

The level of creativity required for your communication piece is determined by what it needs to communicate, who it needs to communicate to, and where it will be presented. A message written for an on-campus audience or to represent the university in an official capacity should be written in a more formal tone than messages to promote an off-campus informal event aimed at students.


Choose appropriate language

The words we use to describe an event or program are as important as the images, logos, and colors we use. Choose language that supports the mission of BYU-Idaho and the mission of your area.


Ask yourself questions about the language in the piece. For example:

  • What connotations do the chosen language and phrases have in popular culture?
  • Do any of the phrases or language paint a mental image that may be inconsistent with the mission of BYU-Idaho?
  • Does the piece exclude or include my audience?


Questions? Send us an e-mail: ucidentity@byui.edu
